thread.title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Sweet 16 with a look at Canton's OT prowess | High School Insider | with Danny Ventura & Jim Clark
thread.title_full: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Sweet 16 with a look at Canton's OT prowess | High School Insider | with Danny Ventura & Jim Clark | Boston Herald

author: Dan Ventura
title: HIGH SCHOOL FOOTBALL: Sweet 16 with a look at Canton's OT prowess | High School Insider | with Danny Ventura & Jim Clark
text:
One could hardly forgive Canton coach Dave Bohane these days if he started scheduling weekly stress tests.
 The season is just five weeks old, and his Bulldogs have already played in three overtime contests. Add in the fact the other two games were decided by a field goal and you can see the necessity for being proactive about his health.
 “It’s been pretty crazy, especially with the overtime games,” said Bohane, whose team is 4-1. “When I was coaching with Mike Redding at Mansfield, when we went to the Super Bowl, we’d joke about being paid more for going an extra week.
 “The fact that we’ve won all three overtime games says a lot for our kids. They’re a confident group who draw from one another.”
 The seeds for success were planted in the opening game when Joe Bires rushed for a pair of scores and Thomas Monagle kicked a 30-yard field goal to lead Canton past Rockland, 17-14. From there, it became an issue of needing extra time to determine a winner.
 Bedford (14-13), Milford (27-21) and Stoughton (22-21) have all paid the ultimate price for going beyond four quarters with Canton. Bohane gives a lion’s share of the credit to seniors Bires and Jake Ragusa, both of whom have excelled on and off the field.
 “Those two guys are the leaders,” Bohane said. “The other guys feed off those two. They have the attitude that they can play with anybody and the other players are drawing off that.”
 Even if it takes more than 44 minutes to do so.
 QUICK HITTERS : Framingham snapped a 16-game losing streak with a 9-0 victory over Brookline Friday night. Nate Martino’s touchdown pass to Tayeron Campbell in the fourth quarter broke a scoreless tie. . . . Woburn head coach Rocky Nelson was seconds away from his 200th win before Arlington rallied with two late scores to knock off the Tanners, 34-33. The road to 200 won’t get easier as Reading and Melrose are next on the schedule.
Sweet 16
(Last week’s rank in parentheses)
1. (1) XAVERIAN (5-0): Put together the best two-way performance of the season against Brockton.
2. (2) ST. JOHN’S PREP (5-0): Eagles are showing they can win football games in a variety of different ways.
3. (3) MARSHFIELD (5-0): Sent a loud reminder to the Atlantic Coast League about this season’s pecking order.
4. (4) NORTH ATTLEBORO (5-0): Defense is putting up as many points as the offense these days.
5. (5) HOLLISTON (5-0): Solid, workmanlike effort got the job done against Hopkinton.
6. (6) DUXBURY (4-1): Built up a big early lead, then held off Plymouth North in a battle of unbeatens.
7. (7) CENTRAL CATHOLIC (4-1): Huge win over Tewksbury puts the Raiders in driver’s seat in the MVC Large.
8. (11) READING (4-1): Took no prisoners against Belmont Friday night.
9. (8) TEWKSBURY (4-1): Central Catholic coach Chuck Adamopoulos wasn’t lying in August when he said Tewksbury was going to be very good again.
10. (9) ANDOVER (4-1): Offensive shootout against Lowell Friday night.
11. (10) BC HIGH (4-1): Tough battle against much-improved Malden Catholic Friday.
12. (13) MILTON (5-0): Keeps sailing along in the Bay State Herget.
13. (14) MELROSE (5-0): Simply too good for Wilmington Friday night.
14. (NR) BILLERICA (5-0): First appearance in this space since the Nick LaSpada days.
15. (15) EVERETT (2-3): Enjoyed the homecooking against Medford.
16. (16) EAST BRIDGEWATER (5-0): You know coach Shawn Tarpey loved getting star quarterback Ryan Graham back from the injured list.
